Comment: Here's a game where White experiments with a double opening sacrifice and... it works!  Interesting variation for anyone who likes to get their light-squared bishop on c4 early in the game.
Everything normal so far.  White now goes for the super-agressive, and totally unknown, to me, "haywire attack" (if it's not called this, it should be).

But now -
and
and

Gaining (regaining?) equality.  Let's take stock: White has an active Queen, nice dark-squared bishop lines and imminent castling possibilities against a displaced Black King and flat Black pawns.  So, I need to develop all my other pieces but not looking too bad on balance at this point...
Yes - let's get Kingy into safety
Black has nicely developed his k-side Rook and is in danger of attacking White's Queen, so now it's up to Wite to prove he's not just a Queen-slinging loonie.  Here goes -

not 14...Be6 15. QxN
Key move.  White's only chance at going for it now is to attack Black's undeveloped position and, especially, the unprotected King.  The bishop will be wanting to reposition to d4.
All Black's pieces are on the back rank.  The idea is to ttack White's e3 Bishop and provide some piece defence for the King but in the end helps White's Bd4 intent.
